properties.description:
Goosenecks Viewpoint

The Goosenecks State Park Viewpoint is perhaps one of the greatest examples of entrenched meander in all of Utah. Approximately 1000 feet below you, the mighty San Juan River turns and twists, flowing six miles while only advancing one and a half linear miles.

Moon House Ruins

Difficulty: Intermediate

A great hike that has you scaling across a canyon to reach 1,000-year-old ruins. A permit is required from the Kane Gulch Ranger Station.

Fish and Owl Canyon Loop

Difficulty: Difficulty

Great canyon backpacking with incredible scenery, lots of solitude, and interesting archeological sites.

The Narrows of Grand Gulch

Difficulty: Intermediate

This is one of only a few short routes that will let you experience the confines of Grand Gulch. You descend very quickly into the slickrock gorge of Collins Canyon via a well-defined trail passing towers, domes, hoodoos, and overhanging rims.

House on Fire Ruins

Difficulty: Intermediate

This pleasant trail follows a creek bed to visit a modest set of Anasazi ruins. The ease of the trail and the relatively short distance to the 'House On Fire' make this one of the more accessible ruins in the area

Bullet Canyon Trail

Difficulty: Intermediate

Bullet Canyon is a major tributary to Grand Gulch. This popular trail takes you down steep slickrock descends that can be challenging even for experienced hikers.

Kane Gulch Ranger Station

BLM Ranger station. A great resource for current trail conditions and permits.

Valley of the Gods Climbing Area

Difficulty: Various

This is a remote area of high adventure climbing. Mexican Hat is one of the easiest desert summits to reach, and the approach is casual. Valley of the Gods is notorious for loose scary climbing, and this beautiful area is pretty much deserted.
